title: Pillared Metal–Organic Frameworks Based on 6
Layers: Structure Modulation and Sorption Properties
abstract: layers as secondary building units formed by the 1,3,5-tris(

-imidazol-ylphenyl)benzene and targeted metal ions, four pillar-layer metal organic frameworks (MOFs) have been synthesized and characterized. The structure and porous properties of the resulting MOFs could be tuned by modifying the size, geometry, and functional groups of the anionic coligands (pillar).
A series of porous pillar-layer frameworks have been prepared with 1,3,5-tris(
-imidazolylphenyl)benzene (tipb) as the main ligand and dicarboxylic acids as coligands. Our studies have demonstrated that tipb is prone to form a 6

layer with targeted metal ions, which could be utilized to construct pillar-layer frameworks. The structure and porous properties of the resulting metal–organic frameworks could be tuned by modifying the size, geometry, and functional groups of the coligands (pillars). Moreover, gas adsorption measurements revealed that both complexes
text: Porous metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) have attracted great attention in recent years not only for their fascinating architectures and topologies,
but also for their exceptional properties such as gas storage

As such, the controllable synthesis of porous MOFs with particular structures and properties has become one of the most attractive targets in this field. To achieve this goal, many strategies have been developed based on the utilization of various organic ligands with different structures and coordination behaviors. As a class of versatile linkers, imidazole and imidazole-containing ligands have been extensively studied and used in the construction of MOFs according to their potential to produce robust and unique structures.
With our continued effort toward synthesizing functional MOFs, a imidazole-containing ligand, 1,3,5-tris(
), was focused on for its expanded and rigid configuration, which may afford MOFs with large pore volume and surface area. By introducing terephthalic acid (H
pta) as a coligand, we have constructed a MOF with unique dynamic structure transformation properties.
In our further investigations of tipb based MOFs, we found that tipb tends to coordinate with Ni
ions to result in robust layer secondary building units under certain conditions, which could be interlinked by dicarboxylic acid coligands to give porous pillar-layer

MOFs. These results indicated that the structures and properties of tipb based MOFs may be modulated by the rational choice and utilization of dicarboxylate ligands. Herein, we report four porous MOFs, namely, {[Ni(tipb)(pta)]·(solvents)}
obba = 4,4′-oxybisbenzoic acid), based on tipb and different dicarboxylate coligands. These MOFs show tunable interpenetration,
porosity, and topology of frameworks depending on the size, geometry, and functional groups of the coligands used, which deeply affect the gas sorption properties of these MOFs.

All chemicals used for synthesis are of analytical grade and commercially available. IR spectra were measured on a Tensor 27 OPUS (Bruker) FT-IR spectrometer with KBr pellets. The powder X-ray diffraction spectra (PXRD) were recorded on a Rigaku D/Max-2500 diffractometer at 40 kV, 100 mA for a Cu-target tube and a graphite monochromator. Simulation of the XRPD pattern was carried out by the single-crystal data and diffraction-crystal module of the Mercury (Hg) program available free of charge via the Internet at
The ligand was prepared according to a literature procedure.

Gas adsorption measurements were performed using an ASAP 2020 M gas adsorption analyzer. UHP-grade gases were used in measurements. The N
isotherms measurements were preceded at 77 K in a liquid nitrogen bath. The H
sorption isotherms were collected at 77 K in a liquid nitrogen bath and 87 K in a liquid argon bath. The CO
sorption isotherm was collected at 195 K in a dry ice and acetone mixture bath. Before measurements, the samples were soaked in methanol for 7 days to remove DMF and H
O solvates and then filtrated and dried at room temperature. The dry samples were loaded in sample tubes and activated under high vacuum (less than 10

Torr) at 160 °C. About 80–100 mg of degassed samples was used for gas sorption measurements, and the weight of each sample was recorded before and after outgassing to confirm removal of guest molecules. The outgassing procedure was repeated on the same sample between experiments for about 2 h.

From the structure analysis of complexes
, it is observed that tipb ligand is prone to form a 6

ions, which could be used for targeted construction of pillar-layer frameworks with dicarboxyate ligands as pillars. Because of the porous nature of the layer structure, 2-fold interpenetration occurred even with relatively short pta

ligands as pillar. Though the porosity of the resulting frameworks were reduced according to the interpenetration, the MOFs obtained still reveal moderate porosity. Also, it is worth noticing that introducing of −NH

groups in the ligands did not affect the formation of framework structure, suggesting that functional groups could be introduced to modulate the pore structure and pore surface properties of these MOFs.

We systematically investigated the coordination behavior of tipb ligand to find that it readily forms 6

ions under certain conditions, which could be utilized for the construction of pillar-layer MOFs. The structures and porous properties of the resulting MOFs could be modulated by modifying the size, geometry, and functional groups of the dicarboxylate pillar ligands. In addition, complexes
due to the limited pore size, which may be applied in selective adsorption applications.

Highly porous and robust ionic MOFs with nia topology constructed by connecting an octahedral ligand and a trigonal prismatic metal cluster
Jia, Jiangtao; Sun, Fuxing; Borjigin, Tsolmon; Ren, Hao; Zhang, Tingting; Bian, Zheng; Gao, Lianxun; Zhu, Guangshan

Two non-interpenetrated and isomorphous MOFs with nia topol., cationic JUC-101 (In3O)(TDCPB)(3H2O)·(xGuest) and anionic JUC-102 (Mn3OH)(TDCPB)(3H2O)·(xGuest) (TDCPB = 1,3,5-tris(3,5-di(4-carboxyphenyl-1-yl)phenyl-1-yl)benzene), were synthesized by connecting a trigonal prismatic metal cluster with an octahedral org. ligand.  JUC-101 obtains a BET surface area of 3742 m2 g-1 and can absorb 4.18 % of H2 at 30 atm and 77 K, while JUC-102 can absorb cationic dye mols. and release them under the triggering of ions.
Two unprecedented 10-connected bct topological metal-organic frameworks constructed from cadmium clusters
Song, Wei-Chao; Pan, Qinhe; Song, Peng-Chao; Zhao, Qiang; Zeng, Yong-Fei; Hu, Tong-Liang; Bu, Xian-He

By simply modifying the expansion of ligand tether length, two Cd(ii) metal-org. frameworks have been constructed from linear tetranuclear and trinuclear cadmium clusters, resp., which present an unprecedented 10-connected unimodal bct net.
Secondary building units, nets and bonding in the chemistry of metal-organic frameworks
Tranchemontagne, David J.; Mendoza-Cortes, Jose L.; O'Keeffe, Michael; Yaghi, Omar M.

This crit. review presents a comprehensive study of transition-metal carboxylate clusters which may serve as secondary building units (SBUs) towards construction and synthesis of metal-org. frameworks (MOFs).  We describe the geometries of 131 SBUs, their connectivity and compn.  This contribution presents a comprehensive list of the wide variety of transition-metal carboxylate clusters which may serve as secondary building units (SBUs) in the construction and synthesis of metal-org. frameworks.  The SBUs discussed here were obtained from a search of mols. and extended structures archived in the Cambridge Structure Database (CSD, version 5.28, Jan. 2007) which included only crystals contg. metal carboxylate linkages (241 refs.).
Three-Dimensional Porous Coordination Polymer Functionalized with Amide Groups Based on Tridentate Ligand: Selective Sorption and Catalysis
Hasegawa, Shinpei; Horike, Satoshi; Matsuda, Ryotaro; Furukawa, Shuhei; Mochizuki, Katsunori; Kinoshita, Yoshinori; Kitagawa, Susumu
Journal of the American Chemical Society

To create a functionalized porous compd., amide group was used in porous framework to produce attractive interactions with guest mols.  To avoid H-bond formation between these amide groups the authors' strategy was to build a three-dimensional (3D) coordination network using a tridentate amide ligand as the three-connector part.  From Cd(NO3)2·4H2O and a three-connector ligand with amide groups a 3-dimensional porous coordination polymer (PCP) based on octahedral Cd(II) centers, {[Cd(4-btapa)2(NO3)2]·6H2O·2DMF}n (1a), was obtained (4-btapa = 1,3,5-benzene tricarboxylic acid tris[N-(4-pyridyl)amide]).  The amide groups, which act as guest interaction sites, occur on the surfaces of channels with dimensions of 4.7 × 7.3 Å2.  X-ray powder diffraction measurements showed that the desolvated compd. (1b) selectively includes guests with a concurrent flexible structural (amorphous-to-cryst.) transformation.  The highly ordered amide groups in the channels play an important role in the interaction with the guest mols., which was confirmed by TGA, adsorption/desorption measurements, and x-ray crystallog.  The authors also performed a Knoevenagel condensation reaction catalyzed by 1a to demonstrate its selective heterogeneous base catalytic properties, which depend on the sizes of the reactants.  The solid catalyst 1a maintains its cryst. framework after the reaction and is easily recycled.
Tailor-Made Metal-Organic Frameworks from Functionalized Molecular Building Blocks and Length-Adjustable Organic Linkers by Stepwise Synthesis
Lan, Ya-Qian; Li, Shun-Li; Jiang, Hai-Long; Xu, Qiang

The authors demonstrated a family of diamondoid metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) based on functionalized mol. building blocks (pentanuclear zinc benzotriazolate clusters) and length-adjustable tetracarboxylate org. linkers by using a stepwise synthesis strategy.  The authors have successfully achieved not only design and control to synthesize MOFs, but also the functionalization of both secondary building units (SBUs) and org. linkers in the same MOF for the first time.  Also, the results of N2 and H2 adsorption show that their surface areas and H2 uptake capacities are detd. by the most optimal combination of functional groups from SBUs and org. linkers, interpenetration, and free vol. in this system.  A member of this series, DMOF-6 exhibits the highest surface area and H2 adsorption capacity among this family of MOFs.
A Sodalite-Type Porous Metal-Organic Framework with Polyoxometalate Templates: Adsorption and Decomposition of Dimethyl Methylphosphonate
Ma, Feng-Ji; Liu, Shu-Xia; Sun, Chun-Yan; Liang, Da-Dong; Ren, Guo-Jian; Wei, Feng; Chen, Ya-Guang; Su, Zhong-Min
Journal of the American Chemical Society

A sodalite-type porous metal-org. framework with polyoxometalate templates, H3[(Cu4Cl)3(BTC)8]2[PW12O40]·(C4H12N)6·3H2O (NENU-11; BTC = 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate), was obtained by a hydrothermal reaction.  As a reasonable candidate for eliminating nerve gas, NENU-11 displays good adsorption behavior for di-Me methylphosphonate (15.5 mols. per formula unit).  In virtue of the catalytic activity of polyoxometalate guests, this nerve gas mimic could be facilely decompd. by a hydrolysis reaction.
Protecting group and switchable pore-discriminating adsorption properties of a hydrophilic-hydrophobic metal-organic framework

Mohideen, M. Infas H.; Xiao, Bo; Wheatley, Paul S.; McKinlay, Alistair C.; Li, Yang; Slawin, Alexandra M. Z.; Aldous, David W.; Cessford, Naomi F.; Duren, Tina; Zhao, Xuebo; Gill, Rachel; Thomas, K. Mark; Griffin, John M.; Ashbrook, Sharon E.; Morris, Russell E.

Formed by linking metals or metal clusters through org. linkers, metal-org. frameworks are a class of solids with structural and chem. properties that mark them out as candidates for many emerging gas storage, sepn., catalysis and biomedical applications.  Important features of these materials include their high porosity and their flexibility in response to chem. or phys. stimuli.  Here, a Cu-based metal-org. framework was prepd. in which the starting linker (benzene-1,3,5-tricarboxylic acid) undergoes selective monoesterification during synthesis to produce a solid {[Cu(mmBTC)(H2O)]·1.66H2O} (mmBTC = monomethyl benzene-1,3,5-tricarboxylate) with two different channel systems, lined by hydrophilic and hydrophobic surfaces, resp.  The material reacts differently to gases or vapors of dissimilar chem., some stimulating subtle framework flexibility or showing kinetic adsorption effects.  Adsorption can be switched between the two channels by judicious choice of the conditions.  The monoesterified linker is recoverable in quant. yield, demonstrating possible uses of metal-org. frameworks in mol. synthetic chem. as 'protecting groups' to accomplish selective transformations that are difficult using std. chem. techniques.
3D Porous Metal-Organic Framework Exhibiting Selective Adsorption of Water over Organic Solvents
Gu, Jin-Zhong; Lu, Wen-Guan; Jiang, Long; Zhou, Hong-Cai; Lu, Tong-Bu

A 3D porous metal-org. framework (MOF) with 1D open channels has been constructed hydrothermally using ZnII and a rigid planar ligand IDC3- (imidazole-4,5-dicarboxylate).  This MOF can adsorb water selectively over org. solvents and can be regenerated and reused.  It also represents a rare example of a MOF with open channels that form/collapse reversibly upon hydration/dehydration.
Sulfonate-grafted porous polymer networks for preferential CO2 adsorption at low pressure
Lu, Weigang; Yuan, Daqiang; Sculley, Julian; Zhao, Dan; Krishna, Rajamani; Zhou, Hong-Cai
Journal of the American Chemical Society

A porous polymer network (PPN) grafted with sulfonic acid (PPN-6-SO3H) and its lithium salt (PPN-6-SO3Li) exhibit significant increases in isosteric heats of CO2 adsorption and CO2-uptake capacities.  The IAST calcns. using single-component-isotherm data and a 15/85 CO2/N2 ratio at 295 °K and 1 bar revealed that the sulfonate-grafted PPN-6 networks show exceptionally high adsorption selectivity for CO2 over N2 (155 and 414 for PPN-6-SO3H and PPN-6-SO3Li, resp.).  Since these PPNs also possess ultrahigh physicochem. stability, practical applications in post-combustion capture of CO2 are possible.
High CO2/N2 and CO2/CH4 selectivity in a chiral metal-organic framework with contracted pores and multiple functionalities
Lv, Xiaoxia; Li, Liangjun; Tang, Sifu; Wang, Chao; Zhao, Xuebo

A metal-org. framework with chiral pores and decorated imidazole and Me groups was constructed.  Upon activation, this MOF undergoes a pore contraction and shows very high selectivity for CO2/N2 and CO2/CH4, indicating a synergistic effect of dynamic pores and functional groups.
Imparting functionality to a metal-organic framework material by controlled nanoparticle encapsulation

Lu, Guang; Li, Shaozhou; Guo, Zhen; Farha, Omar K.; Hauser, Brad G.; Qi, Xiaoying; Wang, Yi; Wang, Xin; Han, Sanyang; Liu, Xiaogang; DuChene, Joseph S.; Zhang, Hua; Zhang, Qichun; Chen, Xiaodong; Ma, Jan; Loo, Say Chye Joachim; Wei, Wei D.; Yang, Yanhui; Hupp, Joseph T.; Huo, Fengwei

Microporous metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) that display permanent porosity show great promise for a myriad of purposes.  The potential applications of MOFs can be developed further and extended by encapsulating various functional species (for example, nanoparticles) within the frameworks.  However, despite increasing nos. of reports of nanoparticle/MOF composites, simultaneously to control the size, compn., dispersed nature, spatial distribution and confinement of the incorporated nanoparticles within MOF matrixes remains a significant challenge.  Here, the authors report a controlled encapsulation strategy that enables surfactant-capped nanostructured objects of various sizes, shapes and compns. to be enshrouded by a zeolitic imidazolate framework (ZIF-8).  The incorporated nanoparticles are well dispersed and fully confined within the ZIF-8 crystals.  This strategy also allows the controlled incorporation of multiple nanoparticles within each ZIF-8 crystallite.  The as-prepd. nanoparticle/ZIF-8 composites exhibit active (catalytic, magnetic and optical) properties that derive from the nanoparticles as well as mol. sieving and orientation effects that originate from the framework material.
Isoreticular Chiral Metal-Organic Frameworks for Asymmetric Alkene Epoxidation: Tuning Catalytic Activity by Controlling Framework Catenation and Varying Open Channel Sizes
Song, Fei-Jie; Wang, Cheng; Falkowski, Joseph M.; Ma, Li-Qing; Lin, Wen-Bin
Journal of the American Chemical Society

A family of isoreticular chiral metal-org. frameworks (CMOFs) of the primitive cubic network topol. was constructed from [Zn4(μ4-O)(O2CR)3] secondary building units and systematically elongated dicarboxylate struts that are derived from chiral Mn-Salen catalytic subunits (R).  CMOFs 1-5 were synthesized by directly incorporating three different chiral Mn-Salen struts into the frameworks under solvothermal conditions, and they were characterized by a variety of methods, including single-crystal x-ray diffraction, PXRD, TGA, and 1H NMR.  Although the CMOFs 1 vs. 2 and CMOFs 3 vs. 4 pairs were constructed from the same building blocks, they exhibit two-fold interpenetrated or noninterpenetrated structures, resp., depending on the steric sizes of the solvents that were used to grow the MOF crystals.  For CMOF-5, only a 3-fold interpenetrated structure was obtained due to the extreme length of the Mn-Salen-derived dicarboxylate strut.  The open channel and pore sizes of the CMOF series vary systematically, owing to the tunable dicarboxylate struts and controllable interpenetration patterns.  CMOFs 1-5 are highly effective catalysts for asym. epoxidn. of a variety of unfunctionalized olefins with up to 92% ee.  The rates of epoxidn. reactions strongly depend on the CMOF open channel sizes, and the catalytic activities of CMOFs 2 and 4 approach that of a homogeneous control catalyst.  Probably although the diffusion of bulky alkene and oxidant reagents can be a rate-limiting factor in MOF-catalyzed asym. reactions, the catalytic activity of the CMOFs with large open channels (such as CMOFs 2 and 4 in the present study) is limited by the intrinsic reactivity of the catalytic mol. building blocks.  The CMOF catalysts are recyclable and reusable and retain their framework structures after epoxidn. reactions.  This work highlights the potential of generating highly effective heterogeneous asym. catalysts via direct incorporation of well-defined homogeneous catalysts into framework structures of MOFs.
Encapsulation of Ln3+ hydrate species for tunable luminescent materials based on a porous Cd(ii)-MOF
Chen, Cheng-Xia; Liu, Qi-Kui; Ma, Jian-Ping; Dong, Yu-Bin

This work builds on the recently developed guest-driven approach for the construction of tunable luminescent materials based on porous metal-org. frameworks (MOFs).  The porous heteroatom-rich Cd(ii)-MOF (1) material was obtained by the reaction of Cd(NO3)2 with 3,5-bis(3-carboxyphenyl)-1,2,4-triazole/4,4'-bis(4-pyridyl)ethane in soln.  Compd. 1 features (4,4) sheets which interlock together to generate a 2-fold interpenetrating robust framework contg. ellipse-like channels with pore dimensions of ∼9 × 11 Å.  In particular, 1 is able to trap lanthanide hydrate cationic species such as Eu(H2O)83+ and Tb(H2O)83+ and to sensitize their emissions in the solid state.  Also, the emission colors could be tuned by changing the co-doped Eu3+/Tb3+ ratio in the Cd(ii)-MOF to provide barcode-like luminescent materials.
A Controllable Gate Effect in Cobalt(II) Organic Frameworks by Reversible Structure Transformations
Chen, Qiang; Chang, Ze; Song, Wei-Chao; Song, Han; Song, Hai-Bin; Hu, Tong-Liang; Bu, Xian-He

A [Co1.5(tipb)(SO4)(pta)0.5]DMF1.75 MOF (BP@DMF) has been prepd. and characterized (tipb = 1,3,5-tris(p-imidazolylphenyl)benzene, H2pta = terephthalic acid).  The MOF had ultramicropores in the structure.  When BP@DMF was exposed to air, it converted into [Co1.5(tipb)(SO4)(H2O)3.6](pta)0.5DMFx (RP-H2O) without losing crystallinity, which in turn converted into BP upon slow loss of water.  A sample of BP@CH3OH was obtained from BP@DMF via solvent exchange.  Gas adsorption of CO2, CH4, N2, methanol, ethanol, and water by the BP was studied.  The reversible response of this material to H2O/NH3 makes it a good candidate as a sensor material.
New Microporous Metal-Organic Framework Demonstrating Unique Selectivity for Detection of High Explosives and Aromatic Compounds
Pramanik, Sanhita; Zheng, Chong; Zhang, Xiao; Emge, Thomas J.; Li, Jing
Journal of the American Chemical Society

The authors report a highly luminescent metal-org. framework(MMOF), [Zn2(oba)2(bpy)]·DMA (I) H2oba is 4,4'-oxybis(benzoic acid); bpy is 4,4-bipyridine; DMA is N,N-dimethylacetamide, and its unique photoluminescence (PL) properties. the authors' studies on its guest-free form revealed unique fluorescence quenching and enhancement behavior upon exposure to the vapor of arom. compds. of group A with electron-withdrawing groups and group B with electron-donating groups, resp.  The results demonstrate the exceptional ability of the guest-free form of I to selectively detect explosives of different types (e.g., arom. DNT vs. nonarom. or aliph. dimethyldinitrobutane).  The origin of such an effect can be understood and explained from MO and band structure calcns. as well as a comparison of their electrochem. properties.  Clearly, the nature of the analyte mols. and the electronic structure and porosity of the MMOF all play key roles in the emission properties.
Gas Sorption, Second-Order Nonlinear Optics, and Luminescence Properties of a Series of Lanthanide-Organic Frameworks Based on Nanosized Tris((4-carboxyl)phenylduryl)amine Ligand
He, Yan-Ping; Tan, Yan-Xi; Zhang, Jian

By controlling the pH value of the reaction system, two sets of lanthanide (Ln)-tris((4-carboxyl)phenylduryl)amine (Ln = Ce, Pr, Nd, Sm) frameworks were generated.  Four isostructural noninterpenetrating frameworks (FIR-8 to FIR-11) are constructed from rod-shaped secondary building units and four other isostructural frameworks (FIR-12 to FIR-15) based on single Ln nodes are described as 8-fold interpenetrating dia-type nets.  Gas sorption measurements for FIR-8 give a Langmuir surface area of 633.8 m2·g-1 and a H2 uptake of 165.2 cm3·g-1 at 77 K and 1 atm.  However, FIR-12 with smaller pores can hardly adsorb any N2 and H2.  Because both FIR-8 and FIR-12 crystallize in acentric space group, the second-harmonic generation (SHG) measurements indicate that both of them display strong powder SHG efficiencies, which are ∼8 and 3 times as strong as that of a potassium dihydrogen phosphate powder.  In addn., the fluorescent emissions of all compds. in the solid state were also studied.
Surface nano-architecture of a metal-organic framework
Makiura, Rie; Motoyama, Soichiro; Umemura, Yasushi; Yamanaka, Hiroaki; Sakata, Osami; Kitagawa, Hiroshi

The rational assembly of ultrathin films of metal-org. frameworks (MOFs)-highly ordered microporous materials-with well-controlled growth direction and film thickness is a crit. and as yet unrealized issue for enabling the use of MOFs in nanotechnol. devices, such as sensors, catalysts and electrodes for fuel cells.  Here we report the facile bottom-up fabrication at ambient temp. of such a perfect preferentially oriented MOF nanofilm on a solid surface (NAFS-1), consisting of metalloporphyrin building units.  The construction of NAFS-1 was achieved by the unconventional integration in a modular fashion of a layer-by-layer growth technique coupled with the Langmuir-Blodgett method.  NAFS-1 is endowed with highly cryst. order both in the out-of-plane and in-plane orientations to the substrate, as demonstrated by synchrotron X-ray surface crystallog.  The proposed structural model incorporates metal-coordinated mols. projected from the two-dimensional sheets that allow each further layer to dock in a highly ordered interdigitated manner in the growth of NAFS-1.  We expect that the versatility of the soln.-based growth strategy presented here will allow the fabrication of various well-ordered MOF nanofilms, opening the way for their use in a range of important applications.
Zhou, Hong-Cai; Long, Jeffrey R.; Yaghi, Omar M.
A review is presented on prepn., structure and application of Metal-Org. Frameworks.
Engineering ZIF-8 Thin Films for Hybrid MOF-Based Devices
Lu, Guang; Farha, Omar K.; Zhang, Weina; Huo, Fengwei; Hupp, Joseph T.

By making use of the flexible combinations of our prepn. method for ZIF-8 thin films with photolithog., soft lithog., and sputter coating, we have demonstrated not only the successful patterning of these films but also the fabrication of periodically vertically spaced, ZIF-8/metal hybrid structures.  These structures are capable of behaving as sensors for selected vapors and gases, including H2.  The combined results illustrate the possibility of engineering MOF materials for device applications.  The concepts presented should be extendable to some other prepn. methods for MOF thin films (or membranes)for example, colloidal routes or Langmuir-Blodgett-type layer-by-layer growth, where no special surface modification of platforms is required.  While beyond the scope of the present study, the elec. and catalytic properties of the MOF/metal hybrid structures-esp. when coupled to mol. sieving and sorption behavior-are also likely to be interesting and useful; indeed, these are currently under investigation.
Lanthanide homometallic and d-f heterometallic MOFs from the same tripodal ligand: structural comparison, one photon (OP) vs. two photon (TP) luminescence and selective guest adsorption behavior
Yan, Cheng; Li, Kang; Wei, Shi-Chao; Wang, Hai-Ping; Fu, Lei; Pan, Mei; Su, Cheng-Yong

The authors report the design of a new functionalized tripodal ligand triCB-NTB (4,4',4''-(2,2',2''-nitrilotris(methylene)tris(1H-benzo[d]imidazole-2,1-diyl)tris(methylene))tribenzoic acid) and its assembly of Eu(III) homometallic or Zn(II)-Eu(III) heterometallic lanthanide-based metal-org. frameworks (MOFs).  C3 sym. Eu(III) center is achieved in the homometallic MOF, [Eu(triCB-NTB)]·DMAc·4H2O (1).  The C3 axis of the three coordinated imino N atoms on the propeller-extended central triCB-NTB ligand coincides with the C3 axis that directs the three para-Me carboxylic benzene arms on three surrounding ligands coordinating with the central Eu(III) simultaneously.  Therefore, a (6, 3) pattern is formed in the framework with relatively large porosity.  In the Zn-Eu heterometallic framework, [EuZn(triCB-NTB)(H2O)(Cl)2]·2DMAc·H2O (2), the N atoms on the triCB-NTB are coordinated with Zn(II) and the carboxylic O atoms are coordinated with Eu(III).  A paddle-wheel linked Eu(III)2 cluster is formed and 1-dimensional loop-and-chain structure was obtained.  Two ligands, two Zn ions and two Eu2 clusters constitute one box-like unit on the loop chain.  Due to the noninversion symmetry imposed on the central Eu and the large polarizability of the ligand, both one photon (OP) luminescence based on the energy transfer from the ligand to Eu3+ and two photon (TP) luminescence based on the hypersensitive transition of the Eu3+ ions are obsd. in the two lanthanide-based MOFs.  This satisfies the urgent needs of multi-mode luminescent lanthanide complex.  Simultaneously, N2 gas and selective vapor adsorptions were also detected in the porous structure of complexes 1 and 2 due to their benzene-filled channels.  The six-pointed-star like cavities in 1 can let the gas and vapor mols. go in and out smoothly subject to changes in the pressure, while the narrower and more irregular channels in 2 show irreversible adsorption behavior for benzene and cyclohexane vapor mols. in vacuum under room temp.
An unprecedented 3-D SHG MOF material of silver(I) induced by chiral triple helices
Yang, Huan; Sang, Rui-Li; Xu, Xiang; Xu, Li

An unprecedented 3-dimensional SHG-active metal-org. framework (MOF) of Ag(I), Ag-Amidn (1) (HAmidn: 2-amino-4,5-imidazoledicarbonitrile), was successfully prepd. by employing the new single ligand.  The cooperative coordination of the imidazole and carbonitrile N atoms leads to the chiral triple helixes accounting for the noncentrosym. space group, which are linked together to form a rare 103 topol. structure.  Ag-Amidn (1) with high thermal stability and insoly. may be considered as a potential 2nd-order NLO material.
Directing the Breathing Behavior of Pillared-Layered Metal-Organic Frameworks via a Systematic Library of Functionalized Linkers Bearing Flexible Substituents
Henke, Sebastian; Schneemann, Andreas; Wuetscher, Annika; Fischer, Roland A.
Journal of the American Chemical Society

Flexible metal-org. frameworks (MOFs), also referred to as soft porous crystals (SPCs), show reversible structural transitions dependent on the nature and quantity of adsorbed guest mols.  In recent studies it is reported that covalent functionalization of the org. linker can influence or even integrate framework flexibility (breathing) in MOFs.  However, rational fine-tuning of such responsive properties is very desirable but challenging as well.  Here the authors present a powerful approach for the targeted manipulation of responsiveness and framework flexibility of an important family of pillared-layered MOFs based on the parent structure [Zn2(bdc)2(dabco)]n (bdc = 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate; dabco = 1,4-diazabicyclo[2.2.2]octane).  A library of functionalized bdc-type linkers (fu-bdc), which bear addnl. dangling side groups at different positions of the benzene core (alkoxy groups of varying chain length with diverse functionalities and polarity), was generated.  Synthesis of [Zn2(fu-bdc)2(dabco)]n yields the resp. collection of highly responsive MOFs.  The parent MOF is only weakly flexible; however, the substituted frameworks of [Zn2(fu-bdc)2(dabco)]n contract drastically upon guest removal and expand again upon adsorption of DMF, EtOH, or CO2, etc., while N2 is hardly adsorbed and does not open the narrow-pored form.  These breathing dynamics are attributed to the dangling side chains that act as immobilized guests, which interact with mobile guest mols. as well as with themselves and with the framework backbone.  The structural details of the guest-free, contracted form and the gas sorption behavior (phase transition pressure, hysteresis loop) are highly dependent on the nature of the substituent at the linker and can therefore be adjusted using the authors' approach.  Combining the authors' library of functionalized linkers with the concept of mixed-component MOFs (solid solns.) offers very rich addnl. dimensions of tailoring the structural dynamics and responsiveness.  Implementation of two differently functionalized linkers in varying ratios yields multicomponent single-phased [Zn2(fu-bdc')2x(fu-bdc'')2-2x(dabco)]n MOFs (0 < x < 1) of increased inherent complexity, which feature a nonlinear dependence of their gas sorption properties on the applied ratio of components.  Hence, the responsive behavior of such pillared-layered MOFs can be extensively tuned via an intelligent combination of functionalized linkers.

Reversible Structural Flexibility and Sensing Properties of a Zn(II) Metal-Organic Framework: Phase Transformation between Interpenetrating 3D Net and 2D Sheet
Kim, Yeonga; Song, Jeong Hwa; Lee, Woo Ram; Phang, Won Ju; Lim, Kwang Soo; Hong, Chang Seop

A three-dimensional Zn(II) framework, [Zn4O(L)3(DMF)2]·0.5DMF·H2O (1; H2L = 3,3'-dimethoxybiphenyl-4,4'-dicarboxylic acid) was prepd. under a solvothermal reaction in DMF.  The structure reveals that the 3-fold interpenetration is stabilized in the framework with a distinct secondary building unit [Zn4O(R-CO2)6(DMF)2], slightly different from that of MOF-5.  Phase transformations in 1 occur reversibly via two pathways of solvent exchange/resolvation and activation/resolvation, which is indicative of the presence of extensive structural flexibility.  Nitrobenzene among tested solvents is selectively detected by 1, and the sensing event was operating repeatedly.  The three-dimensional framework of 1 with 3-fold interpenetration is uniquely converted to the two-dimensional Cu phase with no interpenetration, reflecting a drastic dimensionality variation.
Aromatizing Olefin Metathesis by Ligand Isolation inside a Metal- Organic Framework
Vermeulen, Nicolaas A.; Karagiaridi, Olga; Sarjeant, Amy A.; Stern, Charlotte L.; Hupp, Joseph T.; Farha, Omar K.; Stoddart, J. Fraser
Journal of the American Chemical Society

The aromatizing ring-closing metathesis of 4,4'-(2,5-divinyl-1,4-phenylene)dipyridine pillars has been shown to take place inside an extended porous zinc 1,4-dibromo-2,3,5,6-tetrakis(4-carboxyphenyl)benzene paddlewheel framework.  Employing a combination of solvent-assisted pillar exchange and postsynthesis modification using olefin metathesis, the noninterpenetrated SALEM-14 was formed and converted catalytically into PAH-MOF-1 with polycyclic arom. hydrocarbon (PAH) pillars.  The metal-org. framework in SALEM-14 prevents "intermol." olefin metathesis from occurring between the pillars in the presence of the first generation Hoveyda-Grubbs catalyst, while favoring the prodn. of a PAH, which can be released from the framework under acidic conditions in dimethylsulfoxide.

SHELXTL NT, Program for Solution and Refinement of Crystal Structures, Version 5.1;
There is no corresponding record for this reference.
Acta Crystallographica, Section A: Foundations of Crystallography

An account is given of the development of the SHELX system of computer programs from SHELX-76 to the present day.  In addn. to identifying useful innovations that have come into general use through their implementation in SHELX, a crit. anal. is presented of the less-successful features, missed opportunities and desirable improvements for future releases of the software.  An attempt is made to understand how a program originally designed for photog. intensity data, punched cards and computers over 10000 times slower than an av. modern personal computer has managed to survive for so long.  SHELXL is the most widely used program for small-mol. refinement and SHELXS and SHELXD are often employed for structure soln. despite the availability of objectively superior programs.  SHELXL also finds a niche for the refinement of macromols. against high-resoln. or twinned data; SHELXPRO acts as an interface for macromol. applications.  SHELXC, SHELXD and SHELXE are proving useful for the exptl. phasing of macromols., esp. because they are fast and robust and so are often employed in pipelines for high-throughput phasing.  This paper could serve as a general literature citation when one or more of the open-source SHELX programs (and the Bruker AXS version SHELXTL) are employed in the course of a crystal-structure detn.
Single-crystal structure validation with the program PLATON

The results of a single-crystal structure detn. when in CIF format can now be validated routinely by automatic procedures.  In this way, many errors in published papers can be avoided.  The validation software generates a set of ALERTS detailing issues to be addressed by the experimenter, author, referee and publication journal.  Validation was pioneered by the IUCr journal Acta Crystallographica Section C and is currently std. procedure for structures submitted for publication in all IUCr journals.  The implementation of validation procedures by other journals is in progress.  This paper describes the concepts of validation and the classes of checks that are carried out by the program PLATON as part of the IUCr check CIF facility.  PLATON validation can be run at any stage of the structure refinement, independent of the structure detn. package used, and is recommended for use as a routine tool during or at least at the completion of every structure detn.  Two examples are discussed where proper validation procedures could have avoided the publication of incorrect structures that had serious consequences for the chem. involved.
Computer-aided crystallochemical analysis: TOPOS program package
Blatov, V. A.; Shevchenko, A. P.; Serezhkin, V. N.
Russian Journal of Coordination Chemistry (Translation of Koordinatsionnaya Khimiya)

The modern methods of anal. of geometrical and topol. properties of crystal structures, as well as the software for their implementation are reviewed with 44 refs.  The structural-topol. TOPOS program package is described.  This is the 1st program to combine the crystallog. database management system, the std. methods of crystallochem. anal., and new methods invoking parameters of Voronoi-Dirichlet polyhedrons and elements of graph theory.  Examples of implementation of the TOPOS program in studying the structural features of some substances and searching for the crystallochem. regularities are presented for the classes of compds.

Rationally Designed Micropores within a Metal-Organic Framework for Selective Sorption of Gas Molecules
Chen, Banglin; Ma, Shengqian; Zapata, Fatima; Fronczek, Frank R.; Lobkovsky, Emil B.; Zhou, Hong-Cai

A microporous metal-org. framework, MOF, Cu(FMA)(4,4'-Bpe)0.5 (3a, FMA = fumarate; 4,4'-Bpe = 4,4'-Bpe = trans-bis(4-pyridyl)ethylene) was rationally designed from a primitive cubic net whose pores are tuned by double framework interpenetration.  With pore cavities of about 3.6 Å, which are interconnected by pore windows of 2.0 × 3.2 Å, 3a shows highly selective sorption behaviors of gas mols.
Robust metal-organic framework enforced by triple-framework interpenetration exhibiting high H2 storage density
Xue, Ming; Ma, Shengqian; Jin, Zhao; Schaffino, Roxanna M.; Zhu, Guang-Shan; Lobkovsky, Emil B.; Qiu, Shi-Lun; Chen, Banglin

A microporous metal-org. framework, Zn2(CNC)2(DPT)·G [1, CNC = 4-carboxycinnamate; DPT = 3,6-di-4-pyridyl-1,2,4,5-tetrazine; G = guest mols.], was synthesized and structurally characterized by a triply interpenetrated primitive cubic net with 1-dimensional pores of ∼3.7 Å.  1 Is highly robust enforced by triple framework interpenetration through weak van der Waals interactions, thus the activated 1b takes up 1.28% hydrogen gas and exhibits high hydrogen storage d. of 95.2% at 1 atm and 77 K.
A three-dimensional microporous metal-organic framework with large hydrogen sorption hysteresis
Zhong, Di-Chang; Zhang, Wei-Xiong; Cao, Feng-Lei; Jiang, Long; Lu, Tong-Bu

A three-dimensional microporous metal-org. framework [Cd2(Tzc)2]n (2), (Tzc = tetrazole-5-carboxylate) which is formed from reversible dehydration from newly prepd. [Cd2(Tzc)2(H2O)2]n (1), exhibits selective gas adsorption and large H sorption hysteresis.  The crystal structures of 1 and 2 are reported.
Selective gas adsorption and separation in metal-organic frameworks
Li, Jian-Rong; Kuppler, Ryan J.; Zhou, Hong-Cai

A review.  Adsorptive sepn. is very important in industry.  Generally, the process uses porous solid materials such as zeolites, activated carbons, or silica gels as adsorbents.  With an ever increasing need for a more efficient, energy-saving, and environmentally benign procedure for gas sepn., adsorbents with tailored structures and tunable surface properties must be found.  Metal-org. frameworks (MOFs), constructed by metal-contg. nodes connected by org. bridges, are such a new type of porous materials.  They are promising candidates as adsorbents for gas sepns. due to their large surface areas, adjustable pore sizes and controllable properties, as well as acceptable thermal stability.  This crit. review starts with a brief introduction to gas sepn. and purifn. based on selective adsorption, followed by a review of gas selective adsorption in rigid and flexible MOFs.  Based on possible mechanisms, selective adsorptions obsd. in MOFs are classified, and primary relationships between adsorption properties and framework features are analyzed.  As a specific example of tailor-made MOFs, mesh-adjustable mol. sieves are emphasized and the underlying working mechanism elucidated.  In addn. to the exptl. aspect, theor. investigations from adsorption equil. to diffusion dynamics via mol. simulations are also briefly reviewed.  Furthermore, gas sepns. in MOFs, including the mol. sieving effect, kinetic sepn., the quantum sieving effect for H2/D2 sepn., and MOF-based membranes are also summarized (227 refs.).
